clinical_study.brief_title: Yoga and Aerobic Exercise in Epilepsy
clinical_study.official_title: Investigation of the Effects of Yoga and Aerobic Exercise Training on Physical and Mental Health in People With Epilepsy

brief_summary.textblock: In recent years, there is growing interest in illustrating the health benefits of exercise among epilepsy. Although exercise is recommended for patients with epilepsy, there is uncertainty concerning the effects of yoga and aerobic exercise on multiple health outcomes in epilepsy. The aim of this trial is to examine the effects of yoga and aerobic exercise training on physical activity, health-related physical fitness, mental, emotional, and psychological health status, seizure frequency and quality of life.

primary_outcome.description: Physical activity will be objectively monitored with an accelerometer.
Participants will be given a seizure diary and requested to record the number of their seizure.

secondary_outcome.description: The Six-Minute Walk test will be used to determine functional capacity.
Lower body strength will be determined using the 30-second Chair Stand test.
Balance evaluation will be performed with Biodex Balance System.
Body composition measurements will be performed with bioelectrical impedance analyzer.
For the anthropometric measurements, waist and hip circumference will be taken.

secondary_outcome.measure: Trail Making test and Digit Span test
secondary_outcome.description: The Trail Making test and Digit Span test will be used to evaluate for attention.
The Stroop test and Verbal Fluency will be used to evaluate for executive functions.

secondary_outcome.measure: Weschler Memory Scale-Revised Visual Reproduction subtest
secondary_outcome.description: The Weschler Memory Scale-Revised Visual Reproduction subtest will be used to evaluate for visual memory.
The Clock Drawing test will be used to evaluate for visual perception and visual-spatial functions.
The Oktem Verbal Memory Processes test will be used to evaluate for verbal memory performance.

secondary_outcome.measure: Neurological Disorders Depression Inventory for Epilepsy
secondary_outcome.description: The Neurological Disorders Depression Inventory for Epilepsy will be used to evaluate for depression.
Anxiety will be determined by the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7.
The 10-item Perceived Stress Scale will be used to assess subjective stress.
Fatigue will be assessed with the Fatigue Impact Scale.
Sleep quality will be measured using the Pittsburg Sleep Quality Index.

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-31
secondary_outcome.description: It will be used to determine health-related quality of life for epilepsy.

arm_group.description: Participants allocated to the yoga group will receive the yoga-based intervention through an internet-based video conference remotely in real-time. Each class will accommodate a maximum of 5 subjects. A qualified physiotherapist who was a certificated yoga instructor will teach in these classrooms. The 8-week exercise intervention consists of three times per week sessions of yoga.

Participants of the aerobic exercise group will be requested to perform unsupervised aerobic training in the home environment (e.g., at home, park, backyard, or in the local gym). The 8-week exercise intervention consists of three times per week sessions of aerobic exercise. Training will consist of a 10-min warm-up period, aerobic activity, and 5-min cool-down period.

Participants in the wait-list group will be advised to continue their habitual physical activity next to usual medical care. A yoga or aerobic exercise program of 8 weeks will be offered after the ending of the study period.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with epilepsy diagnosed by a neurologist using the International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) criteria,
- Having access to the internet at least three per week.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any history of neurological disorders other than epilepsy,
- Significant physical and cognitive impairments,
- Musculoskeletal comorbid conditions,
- Contraindications for an exercise intervention including diagnosed cardiovascular, pulmonary, or endocrine diseases,
- Pregnancy,
- Mental deficiency or low education level to understand the questionnaires,
- Currently participating in an exercise program,
- Volunteers who miss 3 consecutive intervention sessions, and do not participate in 10% of sessions.
